articles.title: The Sun’s hidden particle engines finally exposed
articles.summary: Solar Orbiter has identified the Sun’s dual “engines” for superfast electrons: explosive flares and sweeping coronal mass ejections. By catching over 300 events close to their origin, the mission has solved key mysteries about how these particles travel and why they sometimes appear late. The findings will improve space weather forecasts and help shield spacecraft and astronauts from solar radiation.
articles.content:
The European Space Agency-led Solar Orbiter mission has split the flood of energetic particles flung out into space from the Sun into two groups, tracing each back to a different kind of outburst from our star.

The Sun is the most energetic particle accelerator in the Solar System. It whips up electrons to nearly the speed of light and flings them out into space, flooding the Solar System with so-called 'Solar Energetic Electrons' (SEEs).

Researchers have now used Solar Orbiter to pinpoint the source of these energetic electrons and trace what we see out in space back to what's actually happening on the Sun. In a paper to be published in Astronomy & Astrophysics on September 1, they explain that they found two kinds of SEE with clearly distinct stories: one connected to intense solar flares (explosions from smaller patches of the Sun's surface), and one to larger eruptions of hot gas from the Sun's atmosphere (known as 'coronal mass ejections', or CMEs).

"We see a clear split between 'impulsive' particle events, where these energetic electrons speed off the Sun's surface in bursts via solar flares, and 'gradual' ones associated with more extended CMEs, which release a broader swell of particles over longer periods of time," says lead author Alexander Warmuth of the Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam (AIP), Germany.

A clearer connection

While scientists were aware that two types of SEE event existed, Solar Orbiter was able to measure a large number of events, and look far closer to the Sun than other missions had, to reveal how they form and leave the surface of our star.

"We were only able to identify and understand these two groups by observing hundreds of events at different distances from the Sun with multiple instruments - something that only Solar Orbiter can do," adds Alexander. "By going so close to our star, we could measure the particles in a 'pristine' early state and thus accurately determine the time and place they started at the Sun."

Flight delays

The researchers detected the SEE events at different distances from the Sun. This let them study how the electrons behave as they travel through the Solar System, answering a lingering question about these energetic particles.

When we spot a flare or a CME, there's often an apparent lag between what we see taking place at the Sun, and the release of energetic electrons into space. In extreme cases, the particles seem to take hours to escape. Why?

"It turns out that this is at least partly related to how the electrons travel through space - it could be a lag in release, but also a lag in detection," says co-author and ESA Research Fellow Laura Rodríguez-García. "The electrons encounter turbulence, get scattered in different directions, and so on, so we don't spot them immediately. These effects build up as you move further from the Sun."

The space between the Sun and the planets of the Solar System isn't empty. A wind of charged particles streams out from the Sun constantly, dragging the Sun's magnetic field with it. It fills space and influences how the energetic electrons travel; rather than being able to go where they like, they are confined, scattered, and disturbed by this wind and its magnetism.

The study fulfils an important goal of Solar Orbiter: to continuously monitor our star and its surroundings to trace ejected particles back to their sources at the Sun.

"Thanks to Solar Orbiter, we're getting to know our star better than ever," says Daniel Müller, ESA Project Scientist for Solar Orbiter. "During its first five years in space, Solar Orbiter has observed a wealth of Solar Energetic Electron events. As a result, we've been able to perform detailed analyses and assemble a unique database for the worldwide community to explore."

Keeping Earth safe

Crucially, the finding is important for our understanding of space weather, where accurate forecasting is essential to keep our spacecraft operational and safe. One of the two kinds of SEE events is more important for space weather: that connected to CMEs, which tend to hold more high-energy particles and so threaten far more damage. Because of this, being able to distinguish between the two types of energetic electrons is hugely relevant for our forecasting.

"Knowledge such as this from Solar Orbiter will help protect other spacecraft in the future, by letting us better understand the energetic particles from the Sun that threaten our astronauts and satellites," adds Daniel. "The research is a really great example of the power of collaboration - it was only possible due to the combined expertise and teamwork of European scientists, instrument teams from across ESA Member States, and colleagues from the US."

Looking ahead, ESA's Vigil mission will pioneer a revolutionary approach, operationally observing the 'side' of the Sun for the first time, unlocking continuous insights into solar activity. To be launched in 2031, Vigil will detect potentially hazardous solar events before they come into view as seen from Earth, giving us advance knowledge of their speed, direction and chance of impact.

Our understanding of how our planet responds to solar storms will also be investigated further with the launch of ESA's Smile mission next year. Smile will study how Earth endures the relentless 'wind', and sporadic bursts, of fierce particles thrown our way from the Sun, exploring how the particles interact with our planet's protective magnetic field.

Solar Orbiter is a space mission of international collaboration between ESA and NASA, operated by ESA.

This discovery has a broad positive impact by enhancing space weather forecasting, which is crucial for protecting spacecraft, astronauts, and Earth-based technologies from solar radiation. The article provides detailed context about the findings, their significance, and future missions building on this knowledge, fulfilling the criteria for inspiring good news with substantial real-world benefits.
articles.personality_title: Solar Orbiter reveals two engines behind the Sun’s fast electrons
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Sun sends out very fast electrons into space, but scientists did not fully understand where exactly these particles come from or why they sometimes arrive later than expected.

**What happened** – The European Space Agency’s Solar Orbiter spacecraft studied over 300 events near the Sun and discovered that two different types of solar explosions create these energetic electrons. One type comes from sudden solar flares, which are small but powerful bursts on the Sun’s surface. The other comes from larger eruptions called coronal mass ejections (CMEs), which blow out hot gas and particles over longer times.

**Impact** – This discovery helps explain why energetic electrons sometimes appear late when detected far from the Sun. It’s because the particles travel through a windy, magnetic space environment that can scatter and slow them down. Knowing the two different sources of these particles is important for predicting space weather. This can protect satellites, spacecraft, and astronauts from harmful solar radiation.

**What's next step** – ESA will launch new missions like Vigil in 2031, which will watch the Sun’s side not visible from Earth to give earlier warnings of solar storms. Another mission, Smile, launching next year, will study how Earth’s magnetic field shields us from these particles.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Solar Orbiter’s close study of the Sun has identified two main sources of fast electrons, improving space weather forecasts and helping protect space technology and astronauts.
articles.personality_title_fr: Solar Orbiter révèle les deux moteurs des électrons rapides du Soleil
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Soleil envoie des électrons très rapides dans l’espace, mais les scientifiques ne comprenaient pas complètement d’où venaient ces particules ni pourquoi elles arrivaient parfois en retard.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le vaisseau spatial Solar Orbiter de l’Agence spatiale européenne a étudié plus de 300 événements près du Soleil et a découvert que deux types différents d’explosions solaires créent ces électrons énergétiques. Un type vient des éruptions solaires soudaines, qui sont de petits mais puissants éclats à la surface du Soleil. L’autre vient d’éruptions plus grandes appelées éjections de masse coronale (CME), qui projettent du gaz chaud et des particules sur une plus longue période.

**Impact** – Cette découverte explique pourquoi les électrons énergétiques apparaissent parfois en retard lorsqu’ils sont détectés loin du Soleil. C’est parce que les particules traversent un espace rempli de vent solaire et de champs magnétiques qui peuvent les disperser et les ralentir. Connaître ces deux sources est important pour prévoir le climat spatial, ce qui peut protéger les satellites, les engins spatiaux et les astronautes des radiations solaires.

**Prochaine étape** – L’ESA lancera de nouvelles missions comme Vigil en 2031, qui observera le côté du Soleil invisible depuis la Terre pour donner des alertes plus précoces des tempêtes solaires. Une autre mission, Smile, prévue l’année prochaine, étudiera comment le champ magnétique de la Terre nous protège de ces particules.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’étude rapprochée du Soleil par Solar Orbiter a identifié deux principales sources d’électrons rapides, améliorant les prévisions du climat spatial et aidant à protéger la technologie spatiale et les astronautes.
articles.personality_title_es: Solar Orbiter revela los dos motores detrás de los electrones rápidos del Sol
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Sol envía electrones muy rápidos al espacio, pero los científicos no entendían completamente de dónde vienen estas partículas ni por qué a veces llegan con retraso.

**Qué pasó** – La nave espacial Solar Orbiter de la Agencia Espacial Europea estudió más de 300 eventos cerca del Sol y descubrió que dos tipos diferentes de explosiones solares crean estos electrones energéticos. Un tipo proviene de erupciones solares repentinas, que son estallidos pequeños pero poderosos en la superficie del Sol. El otro proviene de erupciones más grandes llamadas eyecciones de masa coronal (CME), que expulsan gas caliente y partículas durante más tiempo.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento ayuda a explicar por qué los electrones energéticos a veces aparecen tarde cuando se detectan lejos del Sol. Esto se debe a que las partículas viajan a través de un espacio lleno de viento solar y campos magnéticos que pueden dispersarlas y ralentizarlas. Conocer estas dos fuentes es importante para predecir el clima espacial, lo que puede proteger satélites, naves espaciales y astronautas de la radiación solar.

**Próximo paso** – La ESA lanzará nuevas misiones como Vigil en 2031, que observará el lado del Sol que no se ve desde la Tierra para dar alertas anticipadas de tormentas solares. Otra misión, Smile, que se lanzará el próximo año, estudiará cómo el campo magnético de la Tierra nos protege de estas partículas.

**Resumen en una frase** – El estudio cercano del Sol por Solar Orbiter ha identificado dos fuentes principales de electrones rápidos, mejorando las predicciones del clima espacial y ayudando a proteger la tecnología espacial y a los astronautas.

articles.title: A weirdly shaped telescope could finally find Earth 2. 0
articles.summary: Spotting Earth-like planets is nearly impossible with conventional telescopes, but researchers propose a bold fix: a rectangular design that can separate a planet’s faint glow from its blinding star. This approach could uncover dozens of nearby worlds that might host life.
articles.content:
The Earth supports the only known life in the universe, all of it depending heavily on the presence of liquid water to facilitate chemical reactions. While single-celled life has existed almost as long as the Earth itself, it took roughly three billion years for multicellular life to form. Human life has existed for less than one 10 thousandth of the age of the Earth.

All of this suggests that life might be common on planets that support liquid water, but it might be uncommon to find life that studies the universe and seeks to travel through space, like we do. To find extraterrestrial life, it might be necessary for us to travel to it.

However, the vastness of space, coupled with the impossibility of traveling or communicating faster than the speed of light, places practical limits on how far we can roam. Only the closest stars to the sun could possibly be visited in a human lifetime, even by a space probe. In addition, only stars similar in size and temperature to the sun are long-lived enough, and have stable enough atmospheres, for multicellular life to have time to form. For this reason, the most valuable stars to study are the 60 or so sun-like stars that are closer to us than approximately 30 light-years. The most promising planets orbiting these stars would have sizes and temperatures similar to the Earth, so solid ground and liquid water can exist.

A needle in the haystack

Observing an Earth-like exoplanet separately from the star it is orbiting around is a major challenge. Even in the best possible scenario, the star is a million times brighter than the planet; if the two objects are blurred together, there is no hope of detecting the planet. Optics theory says that the best resolution one can get in telescope images depends on the size of the telescope and the wavelength of the observed light. Planets with liquid water give off the most light at wavelengths around 10 microns (the width of a thin human hair and 20 times the typical wavelength of visible light). At this wavelength, a telescope needs to collect light over a distance of at least 20 meters to have enough resolution to separate the Earth from the sun at a distance of 30 light-years. Additionally, the telescope must be in space, because looking through the Earth's atmosphere would blur the image too much. However, our largest space telescope - the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) - is only 6.5 meters in diameter, and that telescope was extremely difficult to launch.

Because deploying a 20-meter space telescope seems out-of-reach with current technology, scientists have explored several alternative approaches. One involves launching multiple, smaller telescopes that maintain extremely accurate distances between them, so that the whole set acts as one telescope with a large diameter. But, maintaining the required spacecraft position accuracy (which must be precisely calibrated to the size of a typical molecule) is also currently infeasible.

Other proposals use shorter wavelength light, so that a smaller telescope can be used. However, in visible light a sun-like star is more than 10 billion times brighter than the Earth. It is beyond our current capability to block out enough starlight to be able to see the planet in this case, even if in principle the image has high enough resolution.

One idea for blocking the starlight involves flying a spacecraft called a 'starshade' that is tens of meters across, at a distance of tens of thousands of miles in front of the space telescope, so that it exactly blocks the light from the star while the light from a companion planet is not blocked. However, this plan requires that two spacecraft be launched (a telescope and a starshade). Furthermore, pointing the telescope at different stars would entail moving the starshade thousands of miles, using up prohibitively large quantities of fuel.

A rectangular perspective

In our paper, we propose a more feasible alternative. We show that it is possible to find nearby, Earth-like planets orbiting sun-like stars with a telescope that is about the same size as JWST, operating at roughly the same infrared (10 micron) wavelength as JWST, with a mirror that is a one by 20 meter rectangle instead of a circle 6.5 meters in diameter.

With a mirror of this shape and size, we can separate a star from an exoplanet in the direction that the telescope mirror is 20 meters long. To find exoplanets at any position around a star, the mirror can be rotated so its long axis will sometimes align with the star and planet. We show that this design can in principle find half of all existing Earth-like planets orbiting sun-like stars within 30 light-years in less than three years. While our design will need further engineering and optimization before its capabilities are assured, there are no obvious requirements that need intense technological development, as is the case for other leading ideas.

If there is about one Earth-like planet orbiting the average sun-like star, then we would find around 30 promising planets. Follow-up study of these planets could identify those with atmospheres that suggest the presence of life, for example oxygen that was formed through photosynthesis. For the most promising candidate, we could dispatch a probe that would eventually beam back images of the planet's surface. The rectangular telescope could provide a straightforward path towards identifying our sister planet: Earth 2.0.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a novel telescope design that could significantly advance the search for Earth-like exoplanets around nearby sun-like stars, potentially identifying dozens of planets that might host life. This represents a meaningful scientific breakthrough with broad implications for humanity's understanding of life in the universe and future space exploration.
articles.personality_title: New rectangular telescope design could spot Earth-like planets nearby
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists want to find planets like Earth that might have life. These planets need to be near stars similar to our sun and close enough to study, within about 30 light-years. But stars are much brighter than their planets, making it very hard to see the planets clearly with current telescopes.

**What happened** – Researchers proposed a new telescope shaped like a long rectangle, about 1 meter wide and 20 meters long. This shape helps separate the faint light of a planet from the bright light of its star. The telescope would work in space using infrared light, similar to the James Webb Space Telescope but with a different mirror shape. By rotating the telescope, it can look for planets all around a star.

**Impact** – This design could find about half of the Earth-like planets near sun-like stars within three years. It avoids the need for very large or complicated telescopes and does not require new technologies that are hard to build. If there is one Earth-like planet per star, this telescope might find around 30 such planets close to us. That would be a big step in discovering potentially habitable worlds.

**What's next step** – Scientists will need to further develop and test this rectangular telescope design to make sure it works as expected. If successful, it could be built and launched to start searching for planets. After finding promising planets, future missions might study their atmospheres or send probes to learn more.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new rectangular space telescope could soon help us find many nearby Earth-like planets by clearly separating their light from their stars.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouveau télescope rectangulaire pourrait détecter des planètes semblables à la Terre à proximité
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques cherchent des planètes comme la Terre qui pourraient abriter la vie. Ces planètes doivent être proches d’étoiles semblables au Soleil et situées à moins de 30 années-lumière pour pouvoir être étudiées. Mais les étoiles sont beaucoup plus brillantes que leurs planètes, ce qui rend leur observation très difficile avec les télescopes actuels.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont proposé un nouveau télescope en forme de long rectangle, environ 1 mètre de large et 20 mètres de long. Cette forme aide à séparer la lumière faible d’une planète de la lumière très brillante de son étoile. Le télescope fonctionnerait dans l’espace en lumière infrarouge, comme le télescope James Webb, mais avec un miroir de forme différente. En faisant tourner le télescope, il peut observer les planètes tout autour d’une étoile.

**Impact** – Ce design pourrait détecter environ la moitié des planètes semblables à la Terre autour d’étoiles comme le Soleil en moins de trois ans. Il évite le besoin de télescopes très grands ou compliqués et ne demande pas de technologies difficiles à construire. S’il y a une planète semblable à la Terre par étoile, ce télescope pourrait en trouver environ 30 à proximité. Ce serait une avancée importante pour découvrir des mondes potentiellement habitables.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques devront continuer à développer et tester ce design de télescope rectangulaire pour s’assurer qu’il fonctionne comme prévu. S’il réussit, il pourra être construit et lancé pour commencer la recherche de planètes. Après avoir trouvé des planètes prometteuses, des missions futures pourraient étudier leurs atmosphères ou envoyer des sondes pour en apprendre davantage.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un nouveau télescope spatial rectangulaire pourrait bientôt nous aider à trouver de nombreuses planètes proches semblables à la Terre en séparant clairement leur lumière de celle de leurs étoiles.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo diseño de telescopio rectangular podría detectar planetas similares a la Tierra cercanos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos quieren encontrar planetas como la Tierra que podrían tener vida. Estos planetas deben estar cerca de estrellas similares al Sol y a menos de 30 años luz para poder estudiarlos. Pero las estrellas son mucho más brillantes que sus planetas, lo que hace muy difícil ver los planetas con los telescopios actuales.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores propusieron un nuevo telescopio con forma de rectángulo largo, de aproximadamente 1 metro de ancho y 20 metros de largo. Esta forma ayuda a separar la luz débil de un planeta de la luz brillante de su estrella. El telescopio funcionaría en el espacio usando luz infrarroja, similar al telescopio James Webb, pero con un espejo de forma diferente. Al girar el telescopio, puede buscar planetas alrededor de una estrella.

**Impacto** – Este diseño podría encontrar cerca de la mitad de los planetas similares a la Tierra alrededor de estrellas parecidas al Sol en menos de tres años. Evita la necesidad de telescopios muy grandes o complicados y no requiere tecnologías difíciles de construir. Si hay un planeta similar a la Tierra por estrella, este telescopio podría encontrar unos 30 cerca de nosotros. Esto sería un gran avance para descubrir mundos potencialmente habitables.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos deberán seguir desarrollando y probando este diseño rectangular para asegurarse de que funciona como se espera. Si tiene éxito, podría construirse y lanzarse para comenzar la búsqueda de planetas. Después de encontrar planetas prometedores, futuras misiones podrían estudiar sus atmósferas o enviar sondas para aprender más.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un nuevo telescopio espacial rectangular podría ayudarnos pronto a encontrar muchos planetas similares a la Tierra cerca de nosotros al separar claramente su luz de la de sus estrellas.
